Chapter 22, Part 3: The Ten Grounds

Their minds were all filled with joy, leaping with boundless delight.
Raining down celestial jeweled flowers, falling like snow,

With one voice extolling the Buddha, speaking such words:

The bodhisattva Moon of Liberation requested Vajra Treasury, saying:
Please explain the causes and conditions of attaining the fifth ground and the characteristics of its practice.
The bodhisattva Vajra Treasury said to the bodhisattva Moon of Liberation:
Buddha's disciple!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, having already perfected the fourth ground, wishing to attain the fifth ground, should use ten kinds of impartial mind.
What are the ten?
First, the impartiality of the Dharma of past buddhas;ğŸ”½Second, the impartiality of the Dharma of future buddhas;
Third, the impartiality of the Dharma of present buddhas;
Fourth, the impartiality of pure precepts;
Fifth, the purity and equality of the mind;
Sixth, the purity and equality of eliminating views, doubts, and remorse;
Seventh, the purity and equality of the path and non-path;
Eighth, the purity and equality of the knowledge and views of practice;
Ninth, the purity and equality of the increasingly superior factors of enlightenment;
Tenth, the purity and equality of transforming sentient beings.
The bodhisattva attains the fifth ground through these ten kinds of pure and equal minds.

The bodhisattva dwelling in the Difficult to Conquer ground, due to skillfully cultivating the bodhisattva teachings, the purity of the profound mind, and seeking the increasingly superior path, is then able to attain the Buddha's;

Because this bodhisattva has attained the power of great vows, because he does not abandon the compassionate mind for all, because he has attained the power of mindfulness and wisdom, because he cultivates merit and wisdom without abandoning them, because he gives rise to skillful means, because he wishes to attain the superior path and the bright observation of the upper stages, because he receives the protection of the spiritual powers of the buddhas, and because he gives rise to a mind of definite nonretrogression, he truly knows the noble truth of suffering, the noble truth of the accumulation of suffering, the noble truth of the cessation of suffering, and the noble truth of the path to the cessation of suffering.

This bodhisattva well knows the truth of the world, well knows the truth of ultimate meaning, well knows the truth of characteristics, well knows the truth of distinctions, well knows the truth of speech, well knows the truth of events, well knows the truth of arising, well knows the truth of the extinction and non-arising of suffering, well knows the truth of entering the path, and well knows the truth of all bodhisattvas sequentially accomplishing the stages and giving rise to the wisdom of the TathÄgata.
The bodhisattva, in order to delight the minds of the assembly, knows the truth of the world;
In order to reach the ultimate one vehicle, he knows the truth of ultimate meaning;ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Knowing the characteristics of various dharmas is knowing the truth of characteristics;
Because dharmas are each different, it is knowing the truth of distinctions;
Discerning the aggregates, realms, and sense-fields is knowing the truth of explanation;
Because of the suffering of body and mind, it is knowing the truth of suffering;
Because of the continuity of birth in various destinies, it is knowing the truth of accumulation;
Because of the ultimate cessation of all afflictions, it is knowing the truth of cessation;
Because of reaching the non-dual Dharma, it is knowing the truth of the path;
With omniscience, knowing all dharmas and sequentially accomplishing all bodhisattva stages is knowing the truth of the wisdom of the TathÄgatas;
Because of the power of faith and understanding, it is knowing the inexhaustible wisdom that is not attained.
The bodhisattva thus, with this wisdom of the truths, knows as it truly is that all conditioned dharmas are false, deceptive, and only temporarily present, deceiving ordinary people;
At that time, the bodhisattva's great compassion towards sentient beings becomes even greater, and the light of great loving-kindness arises.

Attaining such wisdom and power, not abandoning any sentient beings, always seeking the Buddha's wisdom, contemplating all conditioned phenomena as they really are, knowing that sentient beings are born due to ignorance and craving in the past, flowing and turning in birth and death, unable to move from the abode of the five aggregates, increasing the mass of suffering, in which there is no self, no possession of self, no sentient beings, no person, no knower, no life, and the future is also like this;
Thus, although it is nonexistent, the foolish are attached to it, not knowing the ultimate escape or non-escape.
He also thought like this:

'Ordinary beings and sentient beings are very strange. Due to ignorance and foolishness, they have immeasurable bodies that have already ceased, are ceasing, and will cease. In this way, in birth and death, they are unable to give rise to thoughts of disgust with the body, but rather further increase the wheel of suffering in the five paths of rebirth. They are carried away by the waters of birth and death and are unable to return;
Returning to the abode of the five aggregates, unable to let go;

Not knowing, not fearing the four great poisonous snakes, unable to pull out the arrow of pride and views, unable to extinguish the fires of greed, anger, and delusion, unable to destroy the darkness of ignorance and foolishness, unable to dry up the great ocean of attachment, not seeking the great sage and guide with the ten powers, always following the will of Mara in the city of birth and death, always being turned by various evil thoughts and contemplations.

Such suffering, distressed, solitary, and destitute beings have no savior, no shelter, no ultimate path. Only I, alone without equal, cultivate blessings and wisdom, and with this provision, enable these beings to abide in ultimate purity, and attain unobstructed wisdom and power in all dharmas.

Thinking like this, from correct contemplation arises the power of wisdom. The vows made and all wholesome roots are for the sake of delivering sentient beings, for the sake of seeking happiness for all sentient beings, for the sake of benefiting all sentient beings, for the sake of liberating all sentient beings, for the sake of all sentient beings having no suffering, for the sake of all sentient beings having no coarseness, for the sake of the mental purity of all sentient beings, for the sake of taming all sentient beings, and for the sake of fulfilling their vows by extinguishing the suffering and distress of all sentient beings.
This bodhisattva abiding in the Difficult to Conquer Ground, because of not forgetting dharmas, is called a mindful one;
because of definitive wisdom, is called a wise one;
because of knowing the sequence of the meaning of scriptures, is called a path-possessor;
because of protecting oneself and protecting others, is called a self-abashed and ashamed one;
because of not abandoning upholding precepts, is called a firm-minded one;
Because of skillfully contemplating what is possible and what is impossible, he is called the Awakened One;
Because of not following others, he is called the One Who Follows Wisdom;
Because of skillfully discerning the meanings of the chapters and sentences of the Dharma, he is called the One Who Follows Wisdom;
Because of skillfully cultivating meditation and concentration, he is called the One Who Has Attained the Supernormal Powers;
Because of following the worldly Dharma practices, he is called the One Who Has Skillful Means;
Because of skillfully accumulating the provisions of merit and virtue, he is called the One Who Is Never Satisfied;
Because of always seeking the causes and conditions of wisdom, he is called the One Who Never Gives Up;
Because of accumulating the causes and conditions of great kindness and great compassion, he is called the One Who Is Never Weary;
Because of always being mindful, he is called the One Who Is Far Removed from Breaking Precepts;
Because of deeply seeking the Buddha's ten powers, four fearlessnesses, and eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha, he is called the One Who Always Thinks of the Buddha's Dharma;
Because of always causing sentient beings to leave evil and cultivate goodness, he is called the One Who Adorns the Buddha's Land;
Because they plant various merits and adorn the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks, they are called those who practice various good deeds;
Because they seek to adorn the Buddha's body, speech, and mind, they are called those who always practice diligently;
Because they make offerings to all Dharma-expounding bodhisattvas, they are called those who delight in great respect;
Because their minds are unobstructed in the midst of all bodhisattva skillful means, they are called those whose minds are unobstructed;
Because they always delight in teaching and transforming sentient beings, they are called those who are far removed from other thoughts day and night.
When bodhisattvas practice in this way, they use giving to transform sentient beings, and also use kind speech, beneficial conduct, and cooperation to transform sentient beings;

Also, manifesting the physical body to teach and transform sentient beings, also using the Dharma to teach and transform sentient beings, also manifesting the practices of bodhisattvas to teach and transform sentient beings, also manifesting the great matters of the buddhas to teach and transform sentient beings, also manifesting the faults of birth and death to teach and transform sentient beings, also manifesting the benefits of the wisdom of the buddhas to teach and transform sentient beings.
The bodhisattva cultivates in this way, using great spiritual powers and various causes and conditions of skillful means to teach and transform sentient beings.

Although the bodhisattva uses various causes and conditions and skillful means, the mind always abides in the Buddha, not losing the roots of goodness, and also constantly seeking the Dharma that benefits sentient beings even more.

Because the bodhisattva benefits sentient beings, he knows all the scriptures, skills, literature,ğŸ”½mathematics, properties of metals and stones, medical treatments, and dry-boil and leprosy diseases in the world,
possession by ghosts, poisonings, etc., music, singing and dancing, playfulness, joy and entertainment, and the country,

peaceful activities for sentient beings, out of compassion for sentient beings, he manifests such teachings, causing them to enter

Bodhisattvas dwelling in the Difficult to Conquer Ground encounter hundreds of thousands of myriads of millions of Buddhas, respectfully making offerings, venerating and praising them with clothing, food and drink, bedding, medicine, closely listening to the Dharma, and becoming Dharma teachers after hearing the Dharma, expounding the Dharma and benefiting, attaining the supreme hearing samÄdhi, and for hundreds of thousands of myriads of millions of eons not forgetting or losing it, all merit and virtue, becoming even more bright and pure.
It is like refined true gold and mother-of-pearl, their luster becoming even more radiant when polished.
Bodhisattvas dwelling in this ground, by the power of skillful means and wisdom, their merit and virtue become even purer and brighter, unmatched by those in lower grounds;
It is also like the wind holding up the palaces of the sun, moon, stars, and celestial beings, causing them to move without losing their proper course.

In the same way, bodhisattvas dwelling in the Difficult to Conquer Ground, by skillful means and contemplation, their merit and virtue become even more bright and pure, yet they do not attain realization and do not quickly accomplish the unsurpassed path.
Buddha-sons!
This is called the brief explanation of the Bodhisattva's Land of Overcoming Difficulties.

They always give rise to this thought:
'I should be the foremost and supreme among all sentient beings, up to being the reliance for all sentient beings.'

When the bodhisattvas heard the characteristics of the higher grounds being spoken,
In the sky above they rained down various wonderful treasures,

All exclaiming, Excellent! Excellent! Vajra Treasury!

All said these words:

Although the wisdom of quiescence and extinction is abundant, seeking to benefit the world,
One who can extinguish all evils is called a great person.
Thus, the celestial maidens with hundreds of thousands of wonderful voices,
Having praised and sung in this way, they silently gazed at the Buddha.
The bodhisattva Moon of Liberation requested Vajra Treasury, saying:
What characteristics must one have to attain the sixth ground?
The bodhisattva Vajra Treasury said:
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have perfected the five stages, wishing to enter the sixth stage, should use ten equal dharmas.
What are the ten?
First, all dharmas are equal because of having no nature;
second, all dharmas are equal because of having no characteristics;ğŸ”½third, all dharmas are equal because of having no arising;
fourth, all dharmas are equal because of having no formation;
fifth, all dharmas are equal because of being originally pure;
sixth, all dharmas are equal because of having no disputation;
seventh, all dharmas are equal because of not grasping and not rejecting;
eighth, all dharmas are equal because of being separated;
ninth, all dharmas are equal because of being like illusions, dreams, reflections, and the moon in the water;
tenth, all dharmas are equal because of the non-duality of existence and non-existence.
Bodhisattvas, using these ten equal dharmas, attain entry into the sixth stage.

The bodhisattva thus observes the nature of all dharmas and is able to endure them in accordance with [reality]. Attaining the sixth ground, although the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas is not yet manifest, the mind has already accomplished the clear and sharp acceptance in accordance with [reality].

This bodhisattva observes the characteristics of all dharmas in this way, with great compassion as the foremost. Increasing great compassion, he observes the arising and ceasing characteristics of the world.
He thinks like this:
'All the places where beings in the world take rebirth are due to attachment to the self. If one is free from attachment to the self, there is no place of rebirth.

All ordinary beings always follow deviant thoughts, practicing the deviant and false path. Blind with foolishness, they are attached to the self, and give rise to the three kinds of actions: sinful actions, meritorious actions, and immovable actions. Due to these actions, they give rise to defiled mental seeds. Because the mind is defiled, with attachments, they give rise to the body of birth and death;
Namely, karma is the ground, consciousness is the seed, ignorance covers, the water of craving moistens, the mind of self-grasping irrigates, and various views cause it to grow;

Giving rise to the sprout of name-and-form, due to name-and-form, the faculties arise, because the faculties combine, there is contact, from contact, feeling arises, due to pleasant feeling, craving arises, because craving increases, there is grasping, due to the conditions of grasping, there is becoming, giving rise to the five aggregates of existence in becoming is called birth, the transformation of the five aggregates is called aging, the cessation of the five aggregates is called death, due to aging and death, there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress, and the mass of various sufferings;
These twelve links of dependent origination have no one who accumulates them, no one who disperses them, when conditions come together, they exist, when conditions disperse, they do not exist.'
The bodhisattva thus contemplates the twelve links of dependent origination in accordance with the six stages.
He also thinks like this:

Because one does not truly understand the ultimate truth, there is ignorance. Ignorance gives rise to karmic activity, which is called formation. Based on formation, there is the initial consciousness. Together with consciousness, there are the four aggregates that are grasped. Based on the aggregates that are grasped, there is name-and-form. When name-and-form is established, there are the six sense bases. Because the faculties and objects come together, there is contact. Contact serves as a condition for the arising of feeling. The delight in feeling is called craving. The increase of craving is called grasping. The arising of karmic activity from grasping is called becoming. The five aggregates that are the result of karmic activity are called birth. The transformation of the five aggregates is called aging. The destruction of the five aggregates is called death.
When death separates, the burning of the mind out of attachment is called sorrow.
The crying out in a voice is the five consciousnesses as suffering, and the mental consciousness as grief. The increase of sorrow and suffering is called distress.
Thus, it merely gives rise to the great accumulation of suffering.

These twelve links of dependent origination are without self and without what belongs to self, without an agent and without one who causes action. If there is an agent, then there is action; if there is no agent, then there is no action. In the ultimate truth, there is no agent and no action.
' He also thought like this:
'The three realms are false and are merely created by the mind;
The twelve links of dependent origination are all based on the mind. Why is this?

Following events, desire arises in the mind. This mind is consciousness. Events are formations. Because formations deceive the mind, it is called ignorance. The place where consciousness depends is called name-and-form. The growth of name-and-form is called the six sense bases. The combination of the three things is contact. Contact arising together is called feeling. Clinging to the feelings is called craving. Not letting go of craving is called grasping. Their combination is called becoming. The arising of what exists is called birth. The transformation of birth is called aging. The destruction of aging is called death.
Moreover, ignorance has two kinds of activities:
First, delusion in the conditions, second, acting as a cause for formations.
Formations also have two kinds of actions:
First, producing results in the future, second, acting as a cause for consciousness.
Consciousness also has two kinds of actions:
First, being able to receive birth, second, acting as a cause for name-and-form.
Name-and-form also has two kinds of actions:
First, causing consciousness to continue, second, acting as a cause for the six sense bases.
The six sense bases also have two kinds of actions:
First, being able to perceive the six sense objects, second, being able to act as a cause for contact.
Contact also has two kinds of actions:
First, being able to contact the perceived objects, second, being able to act as a cause for feeling.
Feeling also has two kinds of actions:
First, experiencing what is disliked or loved, second, acting as a cause for craving.
Craving also has two kinds of actions:
First, giving rise to craving in the realm of what can be clung to, second, acting as a cause for grasping;
Grasping also has two kinds of actions:
First, being able to increase afflictions, second, acting as a cause for becoming;
Becoming also has two kinds of actions:
First, being able to give rise to other destinies, second, acting as a cause for birth;
Birth also has two kinds of actions:
First, being able to give rise to the five aggregates, second, acting as a cause for old age;
Old age also has two kinds of actions:
First, causing the faculties to mature, second, acting as a cause for death;
Death also has two kinds of actions:
First, destroying the body of the five aggregates, second, causing the continuity to not cease due to not seeing and knowing;
Moreover, as for the condition of ignorance giving rise to formations, ignorance causes formations to not cease and assists in accomplishing formations;
As for formations giving rise to consciousness, it causes consciousness to not cease and assists in accomplishing consciousness;ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
As for consciousness being the condition for name-and-form, it prevents name-and-form from being cut off and assists in the formation of name-and-form;
up to birth being the condition for old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress, it prevents death from being cut off and assists in the formation of death;

Because of the cessation of ignorance, then the formations cease, up to because of the cessation of birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress cease. Because the cause ceases, the effect also ceases.

Moreover, ignorance, craving, and grasping are the three parts that do not cut off the path of afflictions, while formations and becoming are the two parts that do not cut off the path of karma, and the remaining links do not cut off the path of suffering. Because of the continuity of the past and future, these three paths do not cease. These three paths are apart from self and what belongs to self, yet they arise and cease.

Moreover, ignorance and formations are past events, while consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, and feeling are present events, and craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age, and death are future events. Thus, they revolve in the three times;
Because of the cessation of ignorance, the formations cease, which is called the cessation of the continuity of the three times.
Moreover, the twelve links of dependent origination are called the three kinds of suffering:

Ignorance, formations, consciousness, name-and-form, and the six sense bases are called the suffering of change, contact and feeling are called the suffering of suffering, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress are called the suffering of suffering.

Because of the cessation of ignorance, the formations cease, and so on up to because of the cessation of birth, old age and death cease, which is called the cessation of the continuity of the three kinds of suffering.
Moreover, because of ignorance, the formations arise, and when ignorance ceases, the formations cease, because the nature of the formations is empty, and the same is true for the rest.

Because of ignorance, the formations arise, which is called the bondage of arising, and when ignorance ceases, the formations cease, which is called the bondage of cessation, and the same is true for the rest.

Furthermore, the arising of formations due to the condition of ignorance is explained in accordance with the observation of non-existence, and the cessation of formations due to the cessation of ignorance is explained in accordance with the observation of exhaustion. The rest is also like this.
Thus, in reverse and forward order, one observes the twelve links of dependent origination in ten ways, namely:

Ignorance, craving, and grasping are the path of afflictions.
Action and becoming are karma, and the remaining factors are suffering.

Practicing emptiness and non-duality, yet cultivating the mind of compassion and kindness.
Although observing all lands, empty like space,
Yet able to skillfully adorn and purify the Buddha lands;
Although knowing the Buddha's body is the same as the Dharma-nature, without characteristics,
Yet planting the thirty-two and eighty minor marks;
Although knowing the Dharma of sound is the characteristic of inexpressibility,
Yet praising the Buddha's voice, causing all to rejoice;
Although knowing the Buddhas attain enlightenment in a single thought,
Yet demonstrating eons and lands, guiding sentient beings.
Knowing the dharmas in this way, one attains the illumination of the Dharma;
The bodhisattva like this then enters the seventh ground.
Abiding in this ground, one is able to contemplate the practices of innumerable sentient beings,
And also know the methods by which the buddhas teach and transform sentient beings.
The number of worlds and kalpas, the various characteristics of phenomena,
And also know the various desires and pleasures of sentient beings.
Knowing how to expound the teachings of the Three Vehicles, causing sentient beings to have faith and understanding,
I should cultivate teaching and transforming, accomplishing these sentient beings.
With such contemplation, skillful means and wisdom are combined,
In the four modes of deportment, always practicing this path.
In every single thought, one is able to perfect the qualities of enlightenment,
Namely, the ten perfections such as giving, morality, and so forth.
Thus, the blessings and virtues cultivated by these bodhisattvas
Are all shared with all sentient beings, called the perfection of giving,
Eliminating the defiled thoughts of the mind, called the perfection of morality,
Not being harmed by the six sense objects, the perfection of forbearance,
Able to give rise to superior dharmas, the perfection of vigor,
Not moving from this path, called the perfection of meditation,
The illumination of the acceptance of non-arising, the perfection of wisdom,
Turning towards the Buddha's path, the perfection of skillful means,
Seeking superior dharmas, called the perfection of vows,
No one is able to destroy it, called the perfection of power,
Able to understand the true teaching, called the perfection of knowledge.
These are the dharmas that assist enlightenment, moment by moment all able to encompass,
Giving rise to vast vows, because they take the great Dharma as their object.
The merits in the first ground are called complete,
The second ground is called the removal of the defilements and evils of the mind,
In the third, vows increase in brightness, in the fourth ground one enters the path,
Fifth, following worldly practices; sixth, entering the profound Dharma,
Obtaining the aspect of non-arising, gradually increasing and growing.
Seventh, gathering all, endowed with the factors of enlightenment,
Able to give rise to all merits and all vows.
Such various merits cause the subsequent eight grounds,
All practices are naturally purified.
The ground of far-reaching is difficult to surpass, only one with great wisdom can do so,
Like two countries in between, difficult to pass through.
In the seventh ground, unstained like a sage-king,
Although dwelling in this path, not called having surpassed everything.
If reaching the eighth ground, the bodhisattva's ground of wisdom,
At that time, surpassing the realm of thought, dwelling in the realm of wisdom,
Like the Brahma King observing the world, not called a human,
Bodhisattvas are unstained by offenses, like a lotus in water.
Bodhisattvas dwelling in this ground surpass all desires and so forth,
Not called having afflictions, nor called completely extinguished.
Entering this correct path, there are no afflictions,
But because they vow to seek the Buddha way, they are not called extinguishers.
In all worldly matters, scriptures, and skills,
Poetic compositions, spells, and so forth, they naturally become clear.
Cultivating various meditative absorptions and spiritual powers,
Immeasurable minds benefiting the world, all these they are able to accomplish.
At that time, this bodhisattva surpasses the practices of the two vehicles,
Dwelling peacefully in the seventh ground, among the practices of bodhisattvas.
Because from the initial arousal of the mind, the power of great vows is superior,
Now in this ground, it is through the power of wisdom.
Just like the prince of a country, when born his surname is noble,
Later, through accomplishing his merits and practices, he becomes supreme among people.
Abiding here, he attains profound wisdom, further giving rise to excellent zeal,
Moment by moment entering quiescence, yet also not grasping at realization.
Like a person skillfully sailing a boat into the great ocean,
Although traveling through deep waters and difficulties, he is not harmed.
The bodhisattva's practice becomes increasingly superior, due to skillful means and wisdom,
His merits and virtues are all complete, beyond the world's ability to know.
Making offerings to immeasurable buddhas, his mind becomes increasingly pure,
Like true gold inlaid with various jewels, adorning it.
Attaining the light of the Buddha's wisdom, drying up the water of love's moisture,
Just as the light of the sun and moon can evaporate mud and mire.
